trial_identification.studytitle: A randomised controlled trial of the effects of fruit intake on cardiovascular disease risk factors in children
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A randomised controlled trial of the effects of fruit intake on cardiovascular disease risk factors in children

conditions.healthcondition: Cardiovascular disease risk factors in children

interventions.interventions: Provision of a daily serviing of fruit in the classroom over an 8 week (1 term) period. Fresh seasonal servings of fruit (a choice of apples, oranges, and bananas) were provided on a daily basis
interventions.comparator: Matched control schools with no provision of fruit on a daily basis

primaryOutcome.outcome: cardiovascular risk factors including; - Blood pressure: measured with an automatic BP monitor - Blood cholesterol: measured with point of care Cholestex device - Weight & Height: measured on a weight/height scale - Body Fat: measure using Bio-impedence methods - Physical Fitness: measured using Bench Step Test protocol and 400 m walk/run test
dietary attitude and behaviour was assessed using the dietary assessment questionnaire from the Schools Nutrition Survey

secondaryOutcome.outcome: parental attitude towards dietary intake and physical activity was assesssed using a questionnaire. The parental attitude questionnaire was developed specifically for the study

eligibility.exclusivecriteria: absence from school during the term

trial_design.concealment: Cluster trial - schools were randomised to receive intervention or control. Allocation involved contacting the central administration site where the allocation schedule was held.
trial_design.statisticalmethods: ANCOVA of changes in cardiovascular risk factors adjusting for baseline levels. Chi squatre analysis of catagorical data Sample size (100 subjects per group) was based on detecting a 10% change in dietary score (25 to 23) with a standard deviation of 5% (80% power and 5% significance level). Assuming 25 students in each class and an ICC of 0.01, a design effect of 25% was added giving a target of 125 subjects per group (250 in total). These estimates were derived from the findings from a pilot Assuming a 10% drop study conducted to determine study feasibility (Chellappha, 2012).

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Background Dietary choice habits are known to influence cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk factors, which even in childhood are a predictor of future morbidity. Our objective was determining the impact of a school-based intervention of providing fruit daily in the classroom and its effects on risk factors for CVD, and dietary behavior. Methods The study was a randomized controlled trial involving two public and two private schools, one of each in an intervention and control group. Measurement at both the start and end of eight weeks aimed to identify any changes in physiological measures, child and parental attitudes and food choices. Results The intervention had minimal impact on physiological variables, but was effective in improving the amount of fruit and vegetables consumed and attitudes towards fruit intake. Parent lifestyle and dietary choices were poor at baseline, but significantly improved in parents of children in the intervention group compared to the control group. Conclusion This intervention was effective in improving the amount of fruit consumed and attitudes towards fruit intake over just 2 months. It has also shown the importance of not just the school environment but also suggests the home environment can influence children developing good dietary choice habits and lifestyle.
ethicsAndSummary.publication: Chellappha, J, Tonkin A, Douglas, E, Reid CM. A pilot study of the effects of fruit intake on cardiovascular risk factors in children. Infant, Child and Adolescent Nutrition, 2012; 4: 348-354.
ethicsAndSummary.publicnotes: The final number of participants was greater than the estimated sample size requirements as all participants in participating classes were included and the class size was essentially the determinant of final numbers.
